root.pub-comments: "The [Torricelli] group is characterized by subject-markers prefixed to verbs, (and some adverbs) varying for person, number, gender (usually), and class (sometimes) of subject…The phonology differs from that of most other Sepik groups in permitting vowel sequences, and in having a large (5-8) number of vowel phonemes." Genetic similarities with the Markham suggest that langauges of the Torricelli area may have once been spoken up the Ramu and into the Markham Valley. There also may be a connection with the aboriginal languages (Senoi, Semang) of Malaysia, but much more research is required before such an assertion can be justifiably made. (Laycock 1973: 7) The popoulation estimates for the langauges in this tree are accurate to 1 January 1970, according to estimates or census data.
root.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 10821. Olo is one of the largest languages spoken in the Sepik area, and therefore has considerable dialect variation, especially between speakers on the coastal side of the range (speaking the Pay dialect) and the southern side (speaking the Wapi dialect). Dialect boundaries, however, cannot be drawn with any certainty. (Laycock 1973: 8-9)

child.pub-comments: Population: 835. Laycock reports that there is no data available on this language, but informants from Mandi and Yamben report that the language is very similar to their own, thus justifying its inclusion within the Marienberg family. (Laycock 1973: 17)

child.pub-comments: Population: 149. Due to the frequent changes in "language allegiance" in villages, the name 'Elepi' is proposed for this language rather than the village name Samap, as Samap is currently occupied by speakers of a different language. Use of the name 'Samap' for this language, therefore, could lead to considerable confusion and should be avoided. 'Elepi' means 'there are none' in the language. Elepi is closely related to Kamasau, but is more than just a dialect- though historically Elepi must have been a dialect of Kamasau due to its absence in existing literature. Laycock states he does not know where Elepi speakers currently reside, given the changed "language allegience" of their historical homeland in Samap. (Laycock 1973: 16)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 1259. Kirschbaum (122, 1926) first documented Buna and compiled an extensive grammar that, unfortunately was destroyed, likely during the Second World War. (Laycock 1973: 16)
child.geography: Ariapan, Boig, Bonam, Gavien, Kasiman, Mambel, Mangen, Mansep, Masan, Suk, Waskurin
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Although Monumbo and Lilau are technically outside the Sepik-Ramu area, they are included to make the Torricelli language family complete. (Laycock 1973: 17)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
